messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:

>> How easy is it for someone
>> trying to learn the API to figure what they need to do and where to
>> get started? Even experienced users can have trouble finding a
>> relatively unfamiliar class, and that's a small API as APIs go, and
>> much better documented than most.
>
> I don't remember having that problem, or having it seen mentioned on the
> mailing list often.

Users rarely recognize or classify the underlying source of their
confusion as poor API design. However, every time someone asks a
mailing list, "How do I do X?" when the answer is sitting right inside
the JavaDocs somewhere is a code smell. I know JUnit fairly well, but
I've still asked one or two questions here that were answered in the API
docs if I'd looked in the right package.

If the API were smaller, easier to search, and easier to comprehend,
then there'd be fewer questions about it. Users would be able to help
themselves more frequently. Size alone is a significant contributor to
complexity. The more methods and classes there are to hunt through, the
harder it is to find what you're looking for. JUnit is a relatively
small and simple API. If it has these problems, imagine how much worse
they are for larger, more complex APIs.
